\begin{soln}
  Consider the function $g(x)=f(x)^{3}+2f(x)-2x-3$.

   It is easy to check that $g(x)$ is continuous over
   $[0,1]$ and differentiable over $(0,1)$.

  Also, $g(0)=g(1)=0$. Therefore by Rolle's Theorem, there
  exists a $c\in (0,1)$ such that $g'(c)=0$.

  Note that $g'(x) = 3f(x)^2\cdot f'(x) + 2f'(x)-2$.

  From here, $g'(c)=0$ implies that,
  \[
    f'(c)=\frac{2}{2+3f(c)^2}
  .\qedhere\]
\end{soln}
